stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and debugs the first Bowser boss fight on the Yoshi-ship level, fixes Reznor lighting, shows new Bowser model, and discusses recent engine optimisations, YouTube move, and release plans.

development_findings.summary: Bowser boss loop defined: slow ‘turtle’ walk → Mario grabs tail → throw Bowser off ship → Lakitu (or jump) returns Bowser to castle; each cycle will get faster and harder.
Implemented Bowser walk‐cycle logic, step-up physics, tail hitbox, grab/release code, dust trail, and pop-in smoothing; still missing final animations and Lakitu pull-back.
Fixed sign and other objects jumping every frame by separating interpolation setup from per-frame offsets.
Huge collision optimisation: keeps original floor-sorting priority, then discards too-high surfaces and iterates only 0x10 bytes (upper & lower Y), cutting memory traffic.
development_findings.quote: Since we need to fix floor clacking … what if we just keep the sorting priority and kill all the floors that are too high, and then we can only iterate 0x10 bytes of each floor.

development_findings.summary: Introduced complex-number GCC trick to return two values (sine & cosine) in one register pair, improving math speed.
development_findings.quote: We’re using imaginary numbers; now I can return two numbers at once.

development_findings.summary: Current ROM size 44.6 MB; 32.1 MB is streamed music. 64 MB limit now mainly a music issue.
Many demo levels (e.g., Bubble-Dome, Zoo) have been completely re-worked; final game is ‘unrecognisable’ compared with 2022 demo.
development_findings.quote: The actual final game is so unrecognisable from the demo right now, it’s actually crazy.

development_findings.summary: Will finish RTYI before porting optimisations back into standard SM64 to avoid duplicate work.
development_findings.quote: It makes no sense to try and make a Mario 64 version now and then have to apply all the optimisations I find to two things at once.

development_findings.summary: Negative-scale mirroring and scale-in animation used to hide pop-in of background ships; still investigating fog/sprite alternatives.
Streamed music chosen for quality despite size; other big technical limit is N64 64 MB maximum and CPU for large dynamic objects.

context_findings.summary: Moved live streams permanently from Twitch to YouTube after polls; prefers 70/30 rev-share vs Twitch 50/50 and dislikes Twitch ads.
context_findings.quote: It seems pretty clear that people prefer YouTube … plus YouTube is 70-30. If you donate on Twitch, Jeff Bezos gets 50%.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: minimise in-game options; too many choices reduce player happiness and fragment experience.
context_findings.quote: Options are bad. The more options there are, the less happy players are; it’s proven.

context_findings.summary: Believes coding skill was ‘innate’; began on a calculator at age 12 and has ~15 years’ experience.
context_findings.quote: I literally was just born with the ability to code. I don’t know why.

context_findings.summary: Works part-time in a professional Unreal Engine job; RTYI is now a spare-time project supported by Patreon/YouTube while saving for a house.
Comments on industry code: AAA discourages ‘good code’ so that average programmers can jump in; Kaze prefers tighter, more optimised code.
context_findings.quote: You can’t really write good code because bad programmers are not gonna be able to work with good code, so the industry discourages it.

context_findings.summary: Will delay open-sourcing RTYI ‘maybe two months’ after release to reduce Nintendo takedown risk and hide Easter eggs.
context_findings.quote: We should probably delay open sourcing the game a little from the initial release, just so Nintendo doesn’t instantly take it down.

biobak.summary: Delivered new tutorial-bunny model (two 48×48 textures + 80×84); Kaze reviewed, adjusted translations and animations.

zeina.summary: Creates animations and artwork; built new, cleaner Bowser model with higher-res textures and better rig; collaborating on animation overhaul.
zeina.quote: I modeled the new Bowser model … gave him a new rig and some higher-res textures.

zeina.summary: Developing a new animation format for Mario; her work doubles as portfolio building.
zeina.quote: Mario’s gonna get a new animation format that Lilaa’s making and that’s gonna fuck a lot of shit up here too.

key_stories.title: Surface-list breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While profiling, Kaze realised Mario 64 wastes cache by loading full surface structs. By discarding floors that are too high and reading only Y-bounds, he halves the cost.
key_stories.challenge: Frame-rate dips from heavy floor iteration.
key_stories.process: Kept Nintendo’s depth sort, killed irrelevant surfaces, used 0x10-byte mini-struct.
key_stories.outcome: Most correct sine/cosine yet and faster collision; daily optimisations continue.
key_stories.key_quote: We can prevent loading this and this, which is very good.

key_stories.title: Abandoning Twitch
key_stories.summary: Community polls showed 80 % prefer YouTube. Combined with Twitch ad fatigue and revenue split, Kaze made a permanent switch.
key_stories.challenge: Choosing a platform that suits community and income.
key_stories.process: Ran test stream, polled audience, compared revenue splits, set up YouTube features.
key_stories.outcome: Streams now exclusively on YouTube; exploring Streamlabs integration for alerts.
key_stories.key_quote: I literally just hate Twitch now; YouTube is 70-30.

key_stories.title: First Bowser fight prototype
key_stories.summary: Kaze live-codes the inaugural Bowser fight: walking AI, tail grab, spin throw, return cycle, and visual polish.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a fresh, memorable boss that respects SM64 mechanics but feels new.
key_stories.process: Implemented walk cycle, step-up, tail hitbox, release physics, debugged angle/translation issues, added dust and pop-in fixes.
key_stories.outcome: Loop is functional but missing animations; Zeina to supply rigs and Lakitu pull-back.
key_stories.key_quote: The first time has to be very easy and then it has to get faster and faster.
